newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU ready to stop excess wheat bids but no decision.
newsitem.headline: EU ready to stop excess wheat bids but no decision.

text.p: The European Commission has not decided whether to accept latest export bids for wheat but is ready to reject all bids if the total volume demanded by traders rises too far, an EU spokesman in Brussels said on Wednesday.
The Commission had on Tuesday rejected bids for over a million tonnes of soft wheat and raised export taxes, saying the amount of licences sought by grain traders had been excessive.
But with the strong dollar making European grain more attractive, traders bid again for at least 277,500 tonnes of soft wheat on Tuesday and an EU response is due by end-week.
"It is too early. There is a decision period of three days. But if in the meantime we get an enormous amount of bids it is possible to reject everything up to then," the spokesman said.
Failing an earlier decision, the results of Tuesday's bids will be known by Friday at the latest, he added.
Traders have been bidding for wheat through the EU's daily mechanism of export licences which have a fixed value, rather than the bid-related values on offer at Thursday tenders.
The tender system is closed until August 14 but the licences that can be bid for daily have the same validity period, currently running up to the end of December.
Traders say the dollar's rise has been encouraging a handful of exporters to take out long-term positions in EU export licences now at comparatively competitive levels despite taxes.
Traders are currently bidding for licences at an export tax of three Ecus per tonne, said to peg French wheat for December at $148-149 per tonne.
